description: Science talk involves discussions about scientific concepts, observations, experiments, and natural phenomena. It includes questioning, predicting, observing, and explaining scientific ideas.
characteristics: Involves questioning and inquiry (why, how, what)
References natural phenomena, experiments, or scientific processes
Uses measurement, comparison, and classification language

examples.text: Look at the plant! It grew bigger. Why did it grow? Because we gave it water and sunlight. The leaves are green now.
Let's do an experiment. What happens if we mix red and blue? I predict it will make purple. Let's test it!
The ice is melting. It's turning into water. Why? Because it's warm in here. Ice melts when it gets hot.
I see a butterfly! It has wings. How does it fly? The wings move up and down. That's how it goes in the air.
The moon is round tonight. Last week it was different. The moon changes shape. Why does it change?
This rock is heavy. This one is light. Let's measure them. The big one weighs more because it's bigger.
The seed needs water to grow. We planted it in soil. Now we wait and see what happens. I think it will sprout.
Look at the clouds. They're moving fast. That means wind. The wind pushes the clouds across the sky.
We mixed colors and made orange. Red and yellow make orange. That's a fact. We proved it with our experiment.
The magnet sticks to the metal. It doesn't stick to plastic. Why? Because magnets only attract certain things.
